title: A Homecoming For Wyatt
text:
October 16, 2015, 6:18 PM by Casey Wonnenberg MONTROSE, SD - 
A small South Dakota town is coming together for one of their own in a big way. 
Eight-year-old Wyatt Hanisch of Montrose is battling a highly aggressive brain tumor, but the community is doing its part to make sure he and his family knows they aren't fighting alone. 
Float prepping for homecoming is an annual tradition in Montrose, but this year the community has a special reason to rally together. 
"I want to brighten his day," third grader Logan Raap said. 
It was just last week when doctors diagnosed Wyatt. 
"I didn't know what to do. I was just thinking about him the whole day. I was just thinking about him the whole day. I didn't know what to do," Raap said. 
Raap can't remember life without Wyatt. 
"He's one of my best friends," Raap said. 
The two met in day care. 
"He's a really good friend," Raap said. 
Friday, not only is the third grade class sporting shirts to honor their friend, but almost every grade, float and fan is becoming a warrior for Wyatt. 
"It's a small community between us and Salem. We all get together when someone is in need. That's what we do," Student Council President Noah Edwards said. 
This parade is just one of many ways the small community is coming together for Wyatt. They've also raised around $1,700 through a penny war in just a few days. 
"We all know Wyatt through church and school," Edwards said. 
While the community is trying to provide strength to the Hanisch family, Wyatt is also proving he's a strong eight year old. Even though he just had radiation Friday morning and isn't feeling well, he still managed to make it to this special occasion. 
"He's cheerful," Raap said. 
An occasion that shows even those who may be small have a big understanding of life's importance. 
"I just want to be there for him. I think of him every day," Raap said. 
"Homecoming this year really brought us all together and made us tighter as a school and a community," Edwards said. 
If you want to help the Hanisch family, you can make a donation to help with medical expenses online . Â© 2015 KELOLAND TV. All Rights Reserved.
